messages.content:
Travers Robert Goff was born in 1863 in London to Irish parents.

Apparently Travers said he born in Ireland, according to Valerie Lawsonâ€™s biography of his famous daughter, Pamela Lyndon Travers aka Helen Lyndon Goff.[1]

Birth: Travers Robert Goff was born on 3 December 1863, parents Henry Lyndon Goff (gentleman) and Charlotte Cecilia Goff of 3 Caledonian Terrace, New Cross, Kent, England, (near Deptford, London). He was baptised 13 January 1864 at Camberwell Christ Church, Surrey.[2][3]

According to Lawson, "Goff was born at home in Queens Road, Deptford, London, in December 1863, the second son of a shipping agent, Henry Lyndon Bradish Goff, and his wife Charlotte Cecilia." Lawson wrote: "he was most in love with the myths of ancient Ireland". This can be seen in the choice of the middle name "Ierne" for his daughter Barbara.[4]

His father died on 26 December 1865, his mother died on 15 November 1870, he was with his stepfather in the 1871 census in London, but his stepfather died on 25 August 1872. What happened to the orphaned Travers Robert Goff?

According to Valerie Lawson, as a young man, not yet twenty, Travers Goff sailed from London to Ceylon, where he was involved in tea planting.

That did not last long, because he was only age 21 when he arrived at Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, in May 1885. "Mr Travers R Goff" was listed as a cabin passenger, in the passenger list of the Sorata, which had left London on 1 April and arrived Sydney on 20 May.[5][6]

He soon became involved in amateur acting, and was the secretary of the Garrick Club in Lismore in 1887, placing the following advertisement in the Northern Star: "THE GARRICK CLUB WILL give their first ENTERTAINMENT on WEDNESDAY EVENING, 10th AUGUST. Proceeds in Aid of the Lismore Hospital. Full particulars in future issue. TRAVERS R. GOFF, Hon. Sec."[7]

Travers was branch manager of the Australian Joint Stock Bank: He was at Moree, where he was involved in community events such as being an MC for the "cinderella dance" in aid of All Saints' Church of England in October 1895.[8]

He was playing cricket at Moree in 1893.[9]

He was a football umpire at Moree in 1896.[10]

He had instructions to close the Moree branch in 1896, and he was Branch Manager at Maryborough in 1896, 1900 at Ipswich, 1902 Brisbane, and finally in 1905 at Allora.[11]

Marriage: Travers married Margaret Agnes Morehead on 9 November 1898 at All Saints' Church, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia. Margaret was the daughter of Robert Charles Morehead & Maria (Jacobs) Morehead.[12]

Their wedding announcement was in The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday 19 November 1898:[13]
They had children:

(1) Helen Lyndon Goff, b. 1899, d. 1996.[14]
(2) Barbara Ierne (Biddy) Goff, b. 1902, d. 1979.[15]
(3) Cicely Margaret (Moya) Goff, b. 1905, d. 1987.



summerize this with the same information and details (dont forget anything)

Travers Robert Goff was born on 3 December 1863 in London to Irish parents Henry Lyndon Goff and Charlotte Cecilia Goff. He grew up in London, but after his parents died, he moved to Ceylon to work in tea planting before eventually settling in Australia in May 1885. There, he became involved in amateur acting and worked as a branch manager for the Australian Joint Stock Bank. Travers married Margaret Agnes Morehead in November 1898, and they had three daughters: Helen Lyndon Goff, Barbara Ierne Goff, and Cicely Margaret Goff. Helen Lyndon Goff, also known as Pamela Lyndon Travers, later became famous as the author of the Mary Poppins series of books.
give me 10 points to describe the chrachtristics of travers robert goff who is pamela travers father

1. Travers Robert Goff was of Irish descent, born in London in 1863.
2. He faced tragedy early in his life, with both parents passing away, leaving him an orphan.
3. Goff had a strong connection to Irish mythology, as seen in the name choices for his daughters.
4. As a young man, he traveled to Ceylon (now, Sri Lanka) for tea planting before settling in Australia.
5. He had a flair for performing arts and was involved in amateur acting and the Garrick Club in Lismore, Australia.
6. Goff held a respectable position as a branch manager for the Australian Joint Stock Bank in various locations across Australia.
7. He was engaged in community events, participating as an MC and sports umpire in his local communities.
8. Goff got married to Margaret Agnes Morehead and had a stable family life.
9. He had three daughters, the eldest of whom, Pamela Lyndon Travers (Helen Lyndon Goff), became a famous author.
10. Despite his hardships, Goff managed to build a life for himself and his family in Australia.

Note: There is limited information available about Travers Robert Goff's personal characteristics, so some points highlight significant events and achievements in his life.
